page.title: 08A VILLAGE CHURCH
page.content: Cranwell village church is dedicated to St. Andrew. It has a Nave, North Aisle, Chancel and South porch. The chancel roof is tiled, and is higher than the flat roof of the Nave. There is a Norman aisle arcade by the side of the nave. The rest of the church was re-built during the early English period. Some of these unusual parts still remain, including the west end of the nave, the aisle, the porch and part of the chancel's south wall with doorway. At the west end of the nave in the gable end is a small stone-bow with a bell, built in the 17th century. The font is a plan early English one, with an octagonal bowl, stem and base. It also has a wooden cover. The north wall was re-built, and the church was extensively restored at the beginning of this century.
